abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Earthquake Recovery
            Project for Colombia was highly satisfactory, the
            sustainability was highly likely, the institutional
            development impact was substantial, and the Bank and
            borrower performance were both satisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicated that after an emergency of this magnitude,
            the local government lacked the resources to cope on their
            own and received little assistance for the first week. Areas
            affected by disasters need immediate assistance from both,
            national governments and international agencies. The
            increased empowerment of beneficiaries enhanced their
            understanding of their rights, responsibilities, and their
            capacity to work together to identify priorities and create
            consensus. Maintaining low overhead costs in the
            Reconstruction Fund for the Coffee Region (FOREC) was
            important. Several of the Non-Governmental Organizations
            lacked sufficient procurement and engineering capacity. The
            reconstruction program was slow to address the needs of rent
            households. The use of "vitrinas inmobiliarias"
            was an innovative and effective way of providing large
            numbers of new housing units by balancing supply and demand.
            The reconstruction of Barrio Brasilia, in the City of
            Armenia, which was devastated by the earthquake, provided
            special lessons in terms of social organization of the
            community and the use of legal instruments for land titling.
